chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Breastfeeding problems - management
chapter.summary: Covers the management of common breastfeeding problems in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 14 years onwards (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage breastfeeding problems?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For all women with breastfeeding problems:
    • Ensure that a person with appropriate training and expertise (such as a health visitor or breastfeeding specialist) observes the woman breastfeeding and expressing milk to check and give advice on:
      • Optimal infant positioning and attachment to the breast.
      • Hand and/or breast pump milk expressing technique; level of suction; and fit of the flange.
      • Initial breast fullness and nipple discomfort in the first few days post-partum which may be normal as the milk 'comes in'. This should improve as maternal milk supply adjusts to the infant's needs.
    • Offer information on local and national breastfeeding support groups and organisations, such as:
      • The Association of Breastfeeding Mothers (website available at https://abm.me.uk/) which has a breastfeeding counsellor telephone helpline (0300 330 5453) and provides written information on breastfeeding issues.
      • The Breastfeeding Network (website available at https://www.breastfeedingnetwork.org.uk/) which runs the national breastfeeding helpline (0300 100 0212) and provides written information on breastfeeding issues.
      • The La Leche League GB (website available at https://www.laleche.org.uk/) which runs a telephone helpline (0345 120 2918), provides online help, runs local meetings, and provides written information on breastfeeding issues.
      • The National Childbirth Trust (website available at https://www.nct.org.uk/) which runs a telephone helpline including breastfeeding support (0300 330 0700), runs antenatal courses, and provides written information on breastfeeding issues and infant feeding.
    • Offer written information on optimal infant positioning and attachment, such as:
      • The NHS A-Z leaflets Breastfeeding: the first few days, Breastfeeding problems, Breast pain and breastfeeding, Sore or cracked nipples when breastfeeding, and Breastfeeding and thrush.
      • The Department of Health leaflet Off to the best start. Important information about feeding your baby which gives tips on breastfeeding technique, indicators of effective attachment, and information on how to express milk.
  • Following assessment and advice on optimal infant positioning and attachment to the breast, if there is suspected:
    • Engorgement:
      • Advise the woman to feed her infant with no restrictions on the frequency or length of feeds.
      • Advise on self-management techniques such as simple analgesia (for example paracetamol) for pain relief, breast massage after feeds, and expressing of milk to relieve full breasts.
      • Advise on the use of heat packs or a warm shower before feeding or expressing milk which can stimulate milk let-down, or the use of cold packs after feeding or expressing, to relieve pain and oedema.
      • Advise on wearing a well-fitting bra and clothing that does not restrict the breasts.
    • Blocked ducts:
      • Advise on feeding from the affected breast frequently.
      • Advise on the use of heat packs or a warm shower for symptom relief.
      • Advise on wearing a well-fitting bra and clothing that does not restrict the breasts.
      • Advise on gentle massage of the breast, using a firm movement towards the nipple, to help relieve the obstruction.
      • If there is a white spot (bleb) on the nipple tip, advise on bathing then rubbing the area with a warm, damp towel.
    • Galactocele:
      • Advise the woman to continue breastfeeding.
      • Refer the woman to a breast specialist to confirm the diagnosis and discuss treatment options, if needed.
      • If there are any clinical features of concern or uncertainty about the diagnosis, see the CKS topic on Breast cancer - recognition and referral for more information on referral pathways.
    • Ductal infection:
      • If bacterial infection is suspected, consider prescribing flucloxacillin 500 mg four times a day for 10–14 days. If the woman is allergic to penicillin, prescribe either erythromycin 250–500 mg four times a day or clarithromycin 500 mg twice a day for 10–14 days. For more prescribing information, see the sections on Flucloxacillin and Erythromycin and clarithromycin in Prescribing information.
      • If Candida infection is suspected, consider prescribing fluconazole 150–300 mg as a single dose followed by 50–100 mg twice a day for 10–14 days, depending on clinical judgement (off-label indication). For more prescribing information, see the section on Fluconazole in Prescribing information.
    • Mastitis or breast abscess:
      • See the CKS topic on Mastitis and breast abscess for detailed information on management in breastfeeding women.
    • Nipple damage:
      • Advise the woman to continue breastfeeding wherever possible, and advise that reducing the duration of feeds is unlikely to relieve nipple pain.
      • Arrange paediatric referral if there is an infant anatomical abnormality such as ankyloglossia (tongue-tie), for consideration of division of the lingual frenulum.
      • Advise on stopping the use of nipple shields or breast shells, if appropriate, as these may contribute to incorrect positioning and attachment.
      • Advise on considering the application of expressed breast milk, if the nipple skin is cracked, fissured, or there is nipple exudate. If symptoms persist, consider whether nipple infection is present.
      • If there is suspected bacterial infection, prescribe fusidic acid 2% cream to be applied to the nipples after every breastfeed for 5–7 days. For more prescribing information, see the section on Topical fusidic acid in Prescribing information.
      • If there is suspected Candida infection, provide treatment for the woman and the infant at the same time, to prevent re-infection. Prescribe miconazole 2% cream to be applied to the nipples after every breastfeed for 2 weeks. For more prescribing information, see the section on Topical miconazole in Prescribing information. If the nipples are red and inflamed, prescribe hydrocortisone 1% cream in addition. For more prescribing information on topical corticosteroids, see the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes. See the CKS topic on Candida - oral for detailed prescribing information on the management of Candida infection in infants.
      • If nipple symptoms persist or are severe, continue topical treatment and consider treating for bacterial or Candida ductal infection, depending on clinical judgement.
    • Skin conditions:
      • If there is suspected eczema, advise on avoiding possible triggers if appropriate, such as lanolin, beeswax, or chamomile in nipple creams; soap, shampoo, and fragrances. Advise on the use of regular emollients and application of a topical corticosteroid to the nipples, immediately after a breastfeed, the potency depending on the severity of the eczema. See the CKS topics on Eczema - atopic and Dermatitis - contact for more information on management.
      • If there is suspected psoriasis, advise on the use of regular emollients and topical treatment to the nipples, immediately after a breastfeed. See the CKS topic on Psoriasis for more information on management.
      • If there is suspected Paget's disease of the nipple, arrange urgent referral to a breast specialist using a suspected cancer pathway. See the CKS topic on Breast cancer - recognition and referral for more information.
    • Nipple vasospasm or Raynaud's disease of the nipple:
      • Advise on avoiding exposure to the cold, wearing warm clothing, and breastfeeding in a warm environment.
      • Advise on self-management techniques such as the use of heat packs or a warm shower following a breastfeed or when there is breast pain.
      • Advise on avoiding caffeine and stopping smoking which can cause vasoconstriction, if appropriate. See the CKS topic on Smoking cessation for more information.
      • If symptoms persist, consider referral to an appropriate specialist, for consideration of a trial of oral nifedipine (off-label indication).
    • Low milk supply:
      • Arrange a paediatric referral for the infant if there are concerns about dehydration, faltering growth, or infant development, the urgency depending on clinical judgement.
      • Manage any underlying cause in the infant or woman that may be contributing to a low milk supply.
      • Advise on increasing skin-to-skin contact (if appropriate); to feed her infant with no restrictions on the frequency or length of feeds; offering both breasts at each feed, and alternating between breasts.
      • Advise on expressing milk after feeds, to stimulate milk production.
      • If these measures do not improve a true low milk supply and maternal prolactin deficiency is a possible cause, consider referral to an endocrinologist for advice on prescribing a galactogogue drug (such as domperidone, off-label indication) to help improve milk supply.
    • Milk oversupply:
      • Ensure that the woman is aware of early feeding cues that suggest an infant is hungry, so that breastfeeds are initiated at appropriate times.
      • Advise that if the infant is unable to attach effectively to the breast due to breast fullness, it may be helpful to express a small amount of milk until the flow slows down, and then try to attach the infant to the breast.
      • Advise on feeding from one breast for each feed, to help reduce milk supply.
      • If a forceful let-down reflex continues, advise the woman that lying down on her back to breastfeed may be helpful.
      • Advise on avoiding milk expression by hand or breast pump between feeds, if possible, to reduce overstimulation of milk supply.
    • If symptoms do not improve as expected with appropriate treatment, consider referral to a breast specialist for further advice on management.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of breastfeeding problems are largely based on expert opinion in the World Health Organization (WHO) publications Mastitis - causes and management [WHO, 2000] and Infant and young child feeding - model chapter for textbooks [WHO, 2009]; the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) interventional procedure guidance Division of ankyloglossia (tongue-tie) for breastfeeding [NICE, 2005] and the NICE clinical guideline Postnatal care up to 8 weeks after birth [NICE, 2006]; the US Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine clinical protocols Use of galactogogues in initiating or augmenting the rate of maternal milk secretion [Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2011], Persistent pain with breastfeeding [Berens et al, 2016], and Engorgement [Berens, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles on breastfeeding problems [Amir, 2014; Amir, 2016], the UK Medicines Information publication Drug treatment of inadequate lactation [UKMi, 2015], and expert opinion in Statements by the National Infant Feeding Network Thrush [National Infant Feeding Network, 2014a] and The use of domperidone in adequate lactation [National Infant Feeding Network, 2014b].

Advice on infant positioning and attachment to the breast
  • This recommendation is based on the fact that most mothers can achieve successful breastfeeding by providing effective attachment at the breast, and feeding according to the infant's needs [NICE, 2006; Amir, 2014].
Suspected engorgement
  • These recommendations are based on the NICE clinical guideline on postnatal care [NICE, 2006], the WHO publication on infant feeding [WHO, 2009] and the ABM clinical protocol on engorgement [Berens, 2016].
  • A Cochrane systematic review of 13 randomized and quasi-randomized controlled trials (919 women) found that the application of chilled cabbage leaves, hot or cold packs, and acupuncture provided some benefit to breastfeeding women with breast engorgement, but the studies were small, heterogenous, and at high risk of bias. It concluded that there was insufficient evidence to recommend any specific intervention [Mangesi, 2016].
Suspected blocked ducts
  • These recommendations are based on the WHO publication on infant feeding [WHO, 2009] and a review article on breastfeeding problems [Amir, 2016].
Suspected galactocele
  • The recommendation on referral if there is any uncertainty about the diagnosis is extrapolated from the WHO publication on mastitis [WHO, 2000]. Ultrasound or aspiration of the breast lump can confirm the diagnosis, and in some cases, treatment with aspiration or surgical excision may be needed.
Suspected ductal infection
  • The recommendations on treatment of suspected Candida infection are extrapolated from the Statement by the NIFN on the treatment of Candida infection of the nipple, which states that ductal infection may require 14–28 days of fluconazole treatment [National Infant Feeding Network, 2014a].
  • CKS did not find any good-quality evidence on the treatment of suspected bacterial ductal infection, so the recommendations on management are extrapolated from the regimens recommended for the treatment of mastitis in breastfeeding women. For more information, see the relevant basis for recommendation section in the CKS topic on Mastitis and breast abscess.
Suspected nipple damage
  • The recommendation on continuing to breastfeed regularly is based on the fact that this is required to maintain sufficient milk production.
  • The recommendation on arranging referral for possible division of ankyloglossia (tongue-tie) is based on the NICE interventional procedure guidance, which found limited evidence that this procedure can improve breastfeeding problems [NICE, 2005], and expert opinion in a review article on nipple pain [Kent et al, 2015].
  • The recommendation on considering the application of expressed breast milk to the nipple is based on a Cochrane systematic review of four heterogenous randomized or quasi-randomized controlled trials (n = 656) of women with nipple pain. The authors concluded that 'the results from these four trials of good methodological quality suggested that applying nothing or just expressed breast milk may be equally or more beneficial in the short-term experience of nipple pain than the application of an ointment such as lanolin.' [Dennis et al, 2014].
  • The recommendation on prescribing topical antibiotics for suspected bacterial infection of the nipple is based on expert opinion in a review article on breastfeeding problems that these agents can help healing [Amir, 2014].
  • The recommendation on prescribing topical and second-line oral antifungal drug treatment for suspected candida infection of the nipple is based on the NIFN statement on candida infection [National Infant Feeding Network, 2014a].
Suspected skin conditions
  • The recommendation to treat eczema or psoriasis of the nipple with topical preparations applied immediately after a breastfeed is based on the fact that this provides maximum contact time before the next breastfeed [Berens et al, 2016].
Suspected nipple vasospasm and Raynaud's disease of the nipple
  • These recommendations are based on an ABM clinical protocol [Berens et al, 2016], expert opinion in review articles on breastfeeding problems [Amir, 2014; Amir, 2016], and a retrospective case review of 22 women with Raynaud's disease of the nipple [Barrett et al, 2013].
  • The recommendation on considering the use of nifedipine is based on the fact that this drug promotes relaxation of vascular smooth muscle cells and leads to vasodilatation, which may provide symptom relief [Barrett et al, 2013; Goundry et al, 2012]. CKS recommends specialist referral before this is started, however, as there is limited evidence on its effectiveness in treating nipple pain, and it is an off-label indication.
Suspected low milk supply
  • The recommendation on ensuring effective infant positioning and attachment is based on the fact that this is needed for an adequate milk supply, so advice and support from a skilled breastfeeding specialist may help to resolve problems of perceived low milk supply [Amir, 2014].
  • The recommendations on self-management strategies to improve milk supply are based on the ABM clinical protocol on the use of galactogogues [Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2011].
  • The recommendation on considering the use of a galactogogue if self-management measures do not help is based on the fact that short-term use of domperidone (a dopamine antagonist, off-label indication) may improve milk supply, as it increases maternal prolactin secretion [Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2011; National Infant Feeding Network, 2014b]. CKS recommends specialist referral before this is started, however, as there is very limited evidence on its effectiveness, and there is no direct correlation between maternal prolactin levels and rates of milk production [Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2011; Amir, 2014; UKMi, 2015].
  • In addition, domperidone has rarely been associated with potentially life-threatening adverse effects, such as ventricular tachyarrhythmias and sudden cardiac death [UKMi, 2015].
Suspected milk oversupply
  • These recommendations are based on the WHO publication on infant feeding [WHO, 2009], expert opinion in a review article on the treatment of maternal milk oversupply [Eglash, 2014], and a review article on breastfeeding problems [Amir, 2016].
  • The recommendation to offer one breast for each feed is based on the 'block feeding' strategy, which allows the other breast to rest, allowing the fullness to provide feedback to the breast to subsequently reduce milk supply [Eglash, 2014; Berens et al, 2016].
Considering referral to a breast specialist if refractory symptoms
  • This recommendation is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
